title: Paresthesia / Numbness / Tingling
scope: ** Systematic evaluation of undifferentiated paresthesia, numbness, or tingling presenting to ED, hospital, or outpatient neurology. Focuses on neuroanatomic localization (peripheral nerve, plexus, root, spinal cord, brainstem/brain), pattern recognition (stocking-glove, dermatomal, hemisensory, non-anatomic), etiologic laboratory workup, electrodiagnostic and imaging indications, and identification of red flags requiring emergent intervention. This is an EVALUATION template. For specific established diagnoses, refer to dedicated plans: Peripheral Neuropathy, Radiculopathy, Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, Small Fiber Neuropathy, GBS, CIDP, Acute Myelopathy, MS - New Diagnosis.

Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; macrocytosis raises suspicion for B12/folate deficiency

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolytes (hypokalemia, hypocalcemia provoke paresthesia), renal dysfunction (uremic neuropathy), hepatic disease, glucose
Diabetes screening; most common cause of polyneuropathy
Diabetes/prediabetes detection; prediabetic neuropathy is underrecognized
B12 deficiency causes large fiber neuropathy and myelopathy (subacute combined degeneration)
If B12 borderline (200-400 pg/mL); more sensitive and specific than B12 alone
Folate deficiency neuropathy; concomitant B12 assessment
Hypothyroidism causes entrapment neuropathy and polyneuropathy
Inflammatory marker; elevated in vasculitis, connective tissue disease
Hypomagnesemia causes paresthesia and tetany; diuretic use, alcoholism
Hypocalcemia causes perioral and acral paresthesia, tetany, Chvostek/Trousseau signs
Hypophosphatemia can cause paresthesia; important if malnourished or refeeding

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Detects impaired glucose tolerance missed by FBG/HbA1c; high yield in idiopathic neuropathy (34-62% have abnormal OGTT)
Monoclonal gammopathy (MGUS, myeloma, amyloidosis) - particularly if sensory-predominant neuropathy
AL amyloidosis, light chain deposition disease
Deficiency OR toxicity (>200 mg/day) both cause neuropathy; ask about supplements
Malabsorption syndromes, cholestasis; causes large fiber sensory neuropathy and ataxia
Copper deficiency (zinc excess, bariatric surgery); myeloneuropathy mimics B12 deficiency
HIV-associated distal sensory polyneuropathy; antiretroviral neurotoxicity
Connective tissue disease screen (lupus, scleroderma, Sjogren)
Sjogren syndrome - common cause of small fiber neuropathy and sensory ganglionopathy
Sarcoidosis - can cause mononeuropathy multiplex or small fiber neuropathy

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If acute onset or motor-predominant (GBS variants); GQ1b for Miller Fisher syndrome
IgM paraproteinemic neuropathy; distal sensory-predominant with tremor and ataxia
Subacute sensory neuronopathy/ganglionopathy; weight loss, smoking history, non-length-dependent pattern
Neuromyotonia, painful neuropathy, Morvan syndrome; cramps with sensory symptoms

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Heavy metal panel (lead, arsenic, thallium, mercury) (CPT 83018, 83015, 83825)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Occupational/environmental exposure; arsenic and thallium cause painful neuropathy
Hereditary neuropathy if family history, pes cavus, slowly progressive from youth; TTR for familial amyloidosis
Small fiber neuropathy confirmation when NCS normal but symptoms persistent
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal IENFD (>8.8 fibers/mm at distal leg; varies by site/age/sex)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Amyloidosis screening if paraprotein present or autonomic features

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Albuminocytologic dissociation in GBS/CIDP; elevated in meningitis, myelitis
Multiple sclerosis if CNS demyelination suspected
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; positive OCBs in 85-95% of MS

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate if acute hemisensory onset with concern for stroke
Immediate if acute onset + stroke suspicion (within treatment window)
Essential/First-line.target: Patent vessels; no large vessel occlusion

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h if acute hemisensory pattern, myelopathy signs, or brainstem signs; ROUTINE if chronic/subacute
Essential/First-line.target: No acute infarct, demyelination, mass, or brainstem lesion

Essential/First-line.timing: Optimal 3-4 weeks after symptom onset (allows Wallerian degeneration); perform earlier if needed
Essential/First-line.target: Characterize axonal vs demyelinating, distribution (length-dependent vs non-length-dependent), motor vs sensory, focal vs diffuse

Extended.item: MRI cervical spine with and without contrast (CPT 72156)
Extended.timing: If myelopathy suspected (bilateral sensory level, UMN signs, bowel/bladder), or cervical radiculopathy
Extended.target: No cord compression, syrinx, demyelination, or enhancement

Extended.item: MRI thoracic spine with and without contrast (CPT 72157)
Extended.timing: If thoracic sensory level identified on exam; bilateral lower extremity numbness
Extended.target: No cord lesion, compression, or transverse myelitis

Extended.item: MRI lumbar spine with and without contrast (CPT 72158)
Extended.timing: Lumbosacral radiculopathy, cauda equina syndrome, lumbosacral plexopathy
Extended.target: No nerve root compression, stenosis, or mass

Extended.timing: Brachial plexopathy, Parsonage-Turner syndrome; unilateral arm weakness with pain
Extended.target: No plexus enhancement, mass, or denervation

Extended.timing: Lumbosacral plexopathy; asymmetric proximal leg weakness and numbness

Extended.item: Autonomic function testing (QSART, tilt table, HRV) (CPT 89240, 95923)
Extended.timing: If autonomic symptoms (orthostasis, anhidrosis, GI dysmotility) accompany sensory symptoms
Small fiber neuropathy evaluation when NCS normal
Entrapment neuropathy (carpal tunnel, cubital tunnel); CIDP (nerve enlargement)
Extended.target: Normal nerve caliber; no focal swelling at entrapment sites

Extended.timing: Lung cancer (paraneoplastic), sarcoidosis, Pancoast tumor (brachial plexopathy)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Focal nerve pathology, plexopathy, peripheral nerve tumor
Occult malignancy if paraneoplastic suspected, amyloidosis
Occult malignancy if paraneoplastic panel positive or unexplained weight loss
Vasculitic neuropathy, amyloidosis, CIDP variants; when non-invasive workup inconclusive
Rare/Specialized.target: No vasculitis, amyloid deposits, or granulomas

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).indication: Acute hemisensory deficit with confirmed acute ischemic stroke within treatment window

dosing.instructions: 0.9 mg/kg IV (max 90 mg); 10% bolus over 1 min, remainder over 60 min

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).contraindications: Active bleeding, recent surgery, INR >1.7, platelets <100K; see Acute Ischemic Stroke plan for full contraindications
Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).monitoring: BP q15min x 2h, then q30min x 6h, then q1h x 16h; neuro checks q15min; bleeding precautions

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).indication: Acute myelopathy with sensory level and suspected inflammatory/demyelinating etiology

doseOptions.orderSentence: Methylprednisolone 1 g IV daily x3-5 days

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily x 3-5 days

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).monitoring: Glucose monitoring Q6h; BP; GI prophylaxis; insomnia management

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).indication: Wernicke encephalopathy prophylaxis in malnourished patients with neuropathic symptoms

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV TID x 3 days, then 250 mg IV daily x 3-5 days, then oral

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).indication: Documented B12 deficiency with neurological symptoms (do not wait for MMA result)

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg IM daily x 7 days, then weekly x 4 weeks, then monthly indefinitely

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).monitoring: Reticulocyte count at 1 week; B12 level at 1-2 months; neurological exam

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).indication: Perioral/acral paresthesia with documented hypocalcemia and tetany

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium gluconate IV (symptomatic hypocalcemia) 1-2 g IV

dosing.instructions: 1-2 g (10-20 mL of 10% solution) IV over 10-20 min; may repeat; follow with continuous infusion if persistent
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium gluconate IV (symptomatic hypocalcemia) 1-2 g IV

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).contraindications: Digoxin use (risk of fatal arrhythmia); hypercalcemia
Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).monitoring: Cardiac monitor during infusion; repeat calcium level q4-6h; ECG

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV over 15-30 min; follow with 4-8 g over 24h

Acute/Emergent (Red Flag Presentations).monitoring: Cardiac monitor; deep tendon reflexes; magnesium level q6-8h; respiratory status

doseOptions.orderSentence: Glucose control optimization Per protocol PO/IV

dosing.instructions: Initiate or intensify glycemic management per diabetes protocol; target HbA1c <7% (individualize); insulin infusion if inpatient with acute hyperglycemia
dosing.orderSentence: Glucose control optimization Per protocol PO/IV

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; increase by 300 mg every 1-3 days; target 900-1800 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Renal impairment (adjust per CrCl: CrCl 30-59 max 900-1400 mg/day; CrCl 15-29 max 600 mg/day; CrCl <15 max 300 mg/day)
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Sedation, dizziness, peripheral edema; taper to discontinue

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; increase to 150 mg BID after 1 week; max 300 mg BID

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Renal impairment (adjust per CrCl); Schedule V controlled substance

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1 week; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; CrCl <30; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Nausea (transient), BP; discontinuation syndrome (taper over 2+ weeks)

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5-75 mg daily; increase by 75 mg every 4-7 days; max 225 mg daily
Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly (anticholinergic burden)
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day; anticholinergic effects; sedation

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly (anticholinergic burden)
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day; anticholinergic effects (fewer than amitriptyline); sedation

dosing.instructions: Apply thin layer TID-QID to affected area; takes 2-4 weeks for effect

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Initial burning (decreases with continued use); wash hands after

dosing.instructions: Applied by healthcare provider for 30-60 minutes; repeat every 3 months

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Apply in clinic; pretreat area with topical lidocaine

dosing.instructions: Apply 1-3 patches to painful area for 12 hours on, 12 hours off

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; application to broken skin

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg BID; increase by 200 mg/day every 3-7 days; max 1200 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: AV block; bone marrow suppression; concurrent MAOIs
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: CBC, LFTs, sodium at baseline and periodically; HLA-B*1502 screening in at-risk populations

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg q6h PRN; ER option: 100 mg daily; max 400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Seizure disorder; concurrent MAOIs; concurrent SSRIs (serotonin syndrome)

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.indication: GBS, CIDP, or other autoimmune neuropathy causing paresthesia/weakness

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ivig 0.4 g/kg IV daily x5 days
Ivig 1 g/kg IV daily x2 days
Ivig 2 g/kg IV divided over 2-5 days

dosing.instructions: 2 g/kg divided over 2-5 days (induction); maintenance 0.4-1 g/kg every 2-4 weeks for CIDP
dosing.orderSentence: Ivig 0.4 g/kg IV daily x5 days

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.contraindications: IgA deficiency (use IgA-depleted product); renal failure; thrombosis risk
Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.monitoring: Renal function, headache, thrombosis, infusion reactions

dosing.instructions: 5-7 exchanges of 1 plasma volume each over 10-14 days
1 mg/kg/day (max 80 mg) x 4-6 weeks; taper over 3-6 months

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.contraindications: Active untreated infection, uncontrolled diabetes, psychosis
Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.monitoring: Glucose, BP, mood, bone density with prolonged use; GI prophylaxis

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.indication: Mild radicular pain, musculoskeletal pain contributing to symptoms

dosing.instructions: 400-600 mg q6-8h PRN; max 2400 mg/day; limit duration

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.contraindications: GI bleeding, renal impairment, concurrent anticoagulation, cardiovascular disease

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.indication: Acute radiculopathy with significant pain and function limitation

doseOptions.orderSentence: Oral corticosteroid taper (cervical/lumbar radiculopathy) 60 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Methylprednisolone dose pack or prednisone 60 mg x 5 days, 40 mg x 5 days, 20 mg x 5 days (15-day taper)
dosing.orderSentence: Oral corticosteroid taper (cervical/lumbar radiculopathy) 60 mg PO

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.contraindications: Active infection, uncontrolled diabetes, GI bleed
Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.monitoring: Glucose; short course so bone density not needed

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.indication: Carpal tunnel syndrome identified as cause

doseOptions.orderSentence: Carpal tunnel splint (wrist neutral) Neutral wrist splint External

dosing.instructions: Neutral wrist splint worn nightly x 4-6 weeks; use during aggravating activities
dosing.orderSentence: Carpal tunnel splint (wrist neutral) Neutral wrist splint External

Condition-Specific Treatments (Initiated.monitoring: Symptom improvement; if no improvement in 6 weeks, pursue injection or surgical referral

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology referral (outpatient) for etiologic workup and localization of all new unexplained paresthesia/numbness
Electrodiagnostic medicine/EMG referral for NCS/EMG characterization when peripheral etiology suspected; optimal timing 3-4 weeks after onset
Stroke team activation for acute hemisensory onset within stroke treatment window; face/arm/leg numbness with other stroke signs
Neurosurgery consult for acute spinal cord compression, cauda equina syndrome, cervical myelopathy with progressive deficit
Physical therapy consult for gait instability from sensory ataxia, balance training, falls prevention, strengthening
Occupational therapy consult for fine motor impairment, ADL difficulty from hand numbness, adaptive strategies
Endocrinology referral for newly diagnosed diabetes/prediabetes with neuropathy; HbA1c not at goal
Rheumatology referral for suspected vasculitic neuropathy, connective tissue disease, Sjogren syndrome
Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain despite multimodal therapy
Hematology/Oncology referral for paraproteinemic neuropathy, suspected malignancy, amyloidosis
Podiatry referral for diabetic neuropathy, foot care education, orthotics, wound prevention
Psychiatry/Psychology referral for functional neurological disorder suspected; chronic pain management; comorbid anxiety/depression
Genetic counseling referral for suspected hereditary neuropathy (CMT, hATTR), positive family history

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED IMMEDIATELY if sudden weakness develops, difficulty walking, loss of bowel/bladder control, or symptoms rapidly worsen over hours
Return to ED if numbness suddenly spreads to face, arm, or leg on one side (possible stroke)
Report if numbness ascends from feet toward trunk (possible GBS)
Track and document when symptoms occur, where they are located, and what makes them better or worse
Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, or wounds if numbness present in feet (use mirror for soles)
Wear well-fitting, protective footwear at all times (never barefoot) if foot numbness present
Test bath water temperature with elbow or thermometer before entering (impaired sensation increases burn risk)
Use night lights and handrails to prevent falls if balance affected
Bring a list of all medications, vitamins, and supplements to neurology appointment (including OTC B6 supplements)
Avoid repetitive wrist motions and use ergonomic positioning if carpal tunnel syndrome suspected
Do not stop prescribed medications abruptly (gabapentin, pregabalin require taper)
Neuropathic pain medications take 2-4 weeks to reach full effect; do not judge effectiveness too early
Avoid excessive alcohol (worsens neuropathy, interacts with pain medications)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict glycemic control if diabetic/prediabetic (HbA1c <7% or individualized target) - most important modifiable factor
Complete alcohol cessation if alcoholic neuropathy suspected (reversible if early)
Regular exercise as tolerated (improves circulation, glycemic control, reduces neuropathic pain)
Review all medications for neurotoxic agents (metronidazole, nitrofurantoin, chemotherapy, amiodarone, isoniazid, linezolid, colchicine, statins)
Avoid excessive vitamin B6 supplementation (>100 mg/day causes sensory neuropathy; very common cause of iatrogenic neuropathy)
Balanced diet rich in B vitamins; supplement B12 if vegan/vegetarian or on metformin
Weight management (reduces pressure on nerves, improves metabolic syndrome)
Fall prevention: remove throw rugs, ensure adequate lighting, use assistive devices if sensory ataxia present
Ergonomic workplace assessment if repetitive motion/compression neuropathy suspected
Compression stocking use for orthostatic symptoms if autonomic involvement

differential.features: Pattern
differential.tests: Key Clinical Features

differential.features: Single nerve distribution (e.g., median, ulnar, peroneal)
differential.tests: Focal numbness/tingling in specific nerve territory; associated weakness in that nerve distribution; Tinel sign at compression site

differential.features: Asymmetric, stepwise involvement of individual nerves
differential.tests: Sequential individual nerve deficits; painful; associated with vasculitis, diabetes, sarcoidosis

differential.features: Stocking-glove distribution, symmetric, starts distally
differential.tests: Feet before hands; gradual proximal spread; associated with diabetes, B12 deficiency, alcohol, medications

differential.features: Non-length-dependent, asymmetric, upper > lower
differential.tests: Patchy sensory loss not following distal-to-proximal gradient; sensory ataxia early; paraneoplastic (anti-Hu), Sjogren

differential.features: Dermatomal distribution, unilateral
differential.tests: Pain radiating in dermatome; positive Spurling test (cervical) or straight-leg raise (lumbar); preserved reflexes outside root

differential.features: Multiple roots/nerves in one limb
differential.tests: Brachial: shoulder/arm pain + weakness + numbness beyond single root; Lumbosacral: thigh pain + proximal weakness

differential.features: Bilateral sensory level, below lesion level
differential.tests: Bilateral numbness below a spinal level; UMN signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski, spasticity); bowel/bladder dysfunction

differential.features: Crossed findings (ipsilateral face + contralateral body)
differential.tests: Lateral medullary syndrome: ipsilateral face numbness + contralateral body numbness; vertigo, ataxia, Horner

differential.features: Hemisensory, contralateral to lesion
differential.tests: Sudden hemisensory loss (stroke); cheiro-oral pattern (thalamic); cortical sensory loss (graphesthesia, stereognosis impaired)

differential.features: Non-anatomic distribution
differential.tests: Midline splitting (vibration), give-way weakness, inconsistent exam, Hoover sign; tubular visual fields

differential.features: Median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle finger, radial ring finger); nocturnal; Phalen/Tinel positive
differential.tests: NCS shows median neuropathy at wrist; ultrasound shows nerve swelling

differential.features: Ring/small finger numbness; hand weakness; positive Froment sign; history of elbow leaning
differential.tests: NCS localizes to elbow; ultrasound shows nerve subluxation or swelling

differential.features: Foot drop; lateral leg/dorsal foot numbness; history of leg crossing, weight loss, prolonged squatting
differential.tests: NCS localizes to fibular head; MRI may show compressive lesion

differential.features: Dermatomal arm numbness (C5-T1); neck pain; Spurling test positive; reflex changes
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine; EMG shows radicular pattern

differential.features: Dermatomal leg numbness (L2-S1); back pain radiating to leg; positive SLR
differential.tests: MRI lumbar spine; EMG shows radicular pattern

differential.features: Symmetric stocking-glove; burning/tingling feet; gradual onset
differential.tests: HbA1c >6.5%; NCS axonal sensorimotor polyneuropathy

differential.features: Large fiber loss (vibration, proprioception); may have myelopathy; macrocytic anemia
differential.tests: B12 <200; MMA elevated; MRI spine may show dorsal column signal

differential.features: Sudden hemisensory onset; resolves within 24h; vascular risk factors
differential.tests: MRI DWI; CTA head/neck; ABCD2 score

differential.features: Acute hemisensory +/- hemiparesis; does not resolve
differential.tests: CT head; MRI DWI; CTA; NIHSS

differential.features: Bilateral sensory level; weakness; bowel/bladder; subacute
differential.tests: MRI spine with contrast (cord enhancement); LP (pleocytosis, OCBs)

differential.features: Relapsing-remitting sensory episodes; young adult; optic neuritis history
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine (demyelinating lesions); OCBs in CSF; McDonald criteria

differential.features: Ascending numbness/weakness over days; areflexia; post-infectious
differential.tests: NCS early may be normal; CSF albuminocytologic dissociation

differential.features: Pain/burning with normal NCS; preserved reflexes; autonomic symptoms
differential.tests: Skin biopsy for IENFD; QSART abnormal; NCS normal

differential.features: Perioral + bilateral hand/foot tingling; situational; respiratory alkalosis
differential.tests: ABG shows respiratory alkalosis; normal exam; symptoms reproduced with hyperventilation

differential.features: Perioral + acral paresthesia; Chvostek and Trousseau signs; tetany
differential.tests: Ionized calcium low; albumin-corrected calcium; PTH

differential.features: Bilateral hand numbness; gait difficulty; upper motor neuron signs; chronic
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine (cord compression, signal change)

differential.features: Upper extremity numbness/pain worse with overhead activity; young women
differential.tests: Roos test, Adson test (low sensitivity); NCS may be normal; MRI/MRA of chest inlet

evidence.recommendation: Systematic approach to evaluation of peripheral neuropathy
evidence.source: [England JD et al. Neurology 2009; AAN Practice Parameter](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19056666/)

evidence.recommendation: Diabetes and prediabetes are most common cause of polyneuropathy in developed countries
OGTT detects IGT in 34-62% of idiopathic neuropathy patients
NCS/EMG for characterization of neuropathy (axonal vs demyelinating)
evidence.source: AAN Practice Parameter; [Cho SC et al. Muscle Nerve 2004](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15389656/)

evidence.recommendation: Gabapentin, pregabalin, duloxetine first-line for neuropathic pain
Tricyclic antidepressants effective for neuropathic pain
SPEP indicated in idiopathic neuropathy workup
Skin biopsy (IENFD) for small fiber neuropathy diagnosis
evidence.source: [Lauria G et al. Eur J Neurol 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20642627/)

evidence.recommendation: B12 deficiency neuropathy: early treatment improves outcomes
Acute stroke: time-critical evaluation of sensory deficits
evidence.source: [Powers WJ et al. AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31662037/)

evidence.recommendation: GBS: IVIG or PLEX within 2 weeks of onset
Hypocalcemia causes perioral and acral paresthesia
evidence.source: Standard physiology texts; [Cooper MS et al. BMJ 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18535072/)

evidence.recommendation: Excessive vitamin B6 causes sensory neuropathy
evidence.source: [Schaumburg H et al. N Engl J Med 1983](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6308447/)

evidence.recommendation: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy: surgical decompression for progressive deficit
evidence.source: [Fehlings MG et al. Global Spine J 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29164035/)

evidence.recommendation: Combination therapy for neuropathic pain improves outcomes

evidence.source: [Brazis PW et al. Localization in Clinical Neurology, 8th ed. 2021]

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; document distribution, modalities affected
monitoring.action: If progressive, escalate workup; repeat imaging; urgent neurology

monitoring.frequency: Every 3 months until stable, then every 6 months
1-2 months after starting supplementation, then annually

monitoring.action: Titrate medications; add adjuncts or refer to pain management
Evaluate for autonomic neuropathy; adjust medications
PT referral; assistive devices; home safety evaluation

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; before gabapentinoid dosing; with renal disease or elderly
monitoring.action: Adjust gabapentin: CrCl 30-59 max 900-1400 mg/day; CrCl 15-29 max 600 mg/day; CrCl <15 max 300 mg/day

monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months if treatment initiated; PRN for symptom change
monitoring.action: If progressive, reconsider diagnosis or escalate therapy

monitoring.frequency: Per etiology (MS: every 6-12 months; myelopathy: per neurosurgery)
monitoring.action: Adjust treatment; neurosurgery referral if progressive compression

monitoring.frequency: Q4h if GBS suspected and ascending; daily if admitted
monitoring.action: ICU transfer if FVC <20 mL/kg or NIF weaker than -30 cm H2O; intubation if declining

monitoring.frequency: After repletion; at follow-up if etiology electrolyte-related

disposition.criteria: Chronic/stable symptoms; no red flags (see below); normal neurological exam or stable chronic findings; no myelopathy signs; no acute weakness; reliable follow-up with neurology within 2-4 weeks; no electrolyte emergency; not stroke presentation

Acute/subacute progressive numbness concerning for GBS or CIDP; new myelopathy signs; significant functional decline; falls from sensory ataxia requiring therapy; severe electrolyte derangement; workup requiring inpatient procedures (LP, nerve biopsy); new-onset mononeuritis multiplex (vasculitis workup)

GBS with respiratory compromise (FVC <20 mL/kg or NIF weaker than -30 cm H2O or declining trajectory); acute spinal cord compression pending emergent surgery; autonomic instability with cardiac arrhythmia or BP lability; acute stroke with hemisensory deficit requiring close monitoring

Stroke presentation requiring thrombectomy-capable center; spinal cord compression requiring emergent neurosurgery not available; NCS/EMG not available for acute evaluation; PLEX/IVIG needed but not available

disposition.disposition: Bilateral sensory level with UMN signs
disposition.criteria: Spinal cord compression or transverse myelitis

disposition.disposition: Acute onset numbness + worst headache of life
